title: 111_s1002
content: The Act titled "Child Care Facilities Financing Act of 2009" includes definitions for key terms. The "Child Care Facilities Financing Act of 2009" defines key terms such as child care facility, child care services, community development financial institution, eligible child, and eligible child care provider. The term "eligible entity" refers to a community development financial institution certified by the Department of the Treasury or an organization described in section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, exempt from taxation under section 501(a) of such Code, and with experience in providing technical assistance. The term "eligible recipient" refers to an eligible child care provider that offers child care services to an eligible child. Eligible recipients may receive assistance for acquiring, constructing, renovating, or improving child care facilities, as well as technical, financial, or managerial support, and help in securing capital financing from private sources. The term "equipment" includes machinery, utilities, necessary structures, furniture, books, and program materials for child care facilities in metropolitan areas. The Community Development Act of 1974 defines the term "Secretary" as the Secretary of Health and Human Services. SEC. 3. TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE GRANTS. The Secretary may grant funds to eligible entities for authorized activities related to child care facilities, prioritizing those with experience in providing technical or financial assistance for facility acquisition or improvement. The Secretary may grant funds to eligible entities for providing technical, financial, or managerial assistance to child care providers in low-income areas, including metropolitan and non-metropolitan communities. Private sources of capital financing are also sought for child care and community development. The Secretary may grant funds to eligible entities for providing assistance to child care providers in low-income areas. Eligible entities must have a median income not exceeding 80 percent of the state's median household income or serve individuals from families with incomes at or below 200 percent of the poverty line. Each eligible entity receiving a grant must deposit the amount into a capital fund. Each eligible entity receiving a grant must deposit the grant amount into a child care capital fund. The fund is used to provide financial assistance for the acquisition, construction, renovation, or improvement of child care facilities, equipment, and technical assistance to eligible child care providers. An eligible entity receiving a loan repayment or investment proceeds must deposit them into the child care capital fund for use as per the section's guidelines. Eligible entities and recipients must submit applications to the Secretary and the entity, respectively, meeting specified requirements. Authorization of appropriations for this section includes $50,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2014.
